title: Effect of PAL Enzyme on Apple Pigments

content.question:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

In response to an increase in the frequency of thunderstorms that produce damaging hail, some apple growers have started to cover their apple orchards with large nets. While these nets protect the apple trees from hail damage, the nets also decrease the amount of light that reaches the trees. In an attempt to reduce the impact of shading by the nets, researchers investigated the ability of different ground covers placed around the base of the trees to reflect light back to the apple trees. An apple orchard with genetically identical apple trees was divided in half. A reflective ground cover was applied to one half of the orchard, while grass was left as the ground cover for the other half. A sample of apples was taken from every tree. The percent of light reflected by the two ground covers was measured at three distances above the ground (Figure 1).

Figure 1. Percent of light reflected by ground covers, measured at three distances above the ground. Error bars equal <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The amount of light that apple trees receive changes the expression of a certain transcription factor. This transcription factor affects the transcription rate of the gene encoding the enzyme phenylalanine ammonium-lyase (<math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).The <math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme is required for the production of two types of pigments, anthocyanins and flavonoids, which contribute to the coloration of apples. Light also affects the activity of the <math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme by a signal transduction pathway (Figure 2).

Figure 2. Simplified model of the signal transduction pathway leading to <math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activation and breakdown

The researchers measured the average concentrations of anthocyanins and flavonoids in apples from trees grown with both types of ground cover (Table 1).

(b) Identify the type of variable represented by the different ground covers used in the researchers' experiment. Justify the measurement of reflected light at three different distances from the ground. Describe the relationship between percent of light reflected and the concentration of pigments in apples. Calculate the concentration of anthocyanin in apples grown with reflective ground cover relative to the concentration of anthocyanin in apples grown without reflective ground cover.

(c) Researchers plan to create a genetically modified strain of apple trees that continually express the gene encoding the kinase associated with the <math alttext="P A L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme (Figure 2). If the researchers were to repeat the ground cover experiment with these genetically modified apple trees, predict the effect of the two ground covers on pigment concentrations in the genetically modified apples. Provide reasoning to justify your prediction.

(d) Based on the information provided in Figure 2, predict the effect of a constantly active phosphatase on anthocyanin pigment production. In leaves, the <math alttext="P A L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme is also required for the production of other molecules that protect the plant against bacterial infections. Explain how covering orchards with nets might affect the trees' resistance to bacterial infections. Explain how a decrease in the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the apple cells will most likely affect the function of the <math alttext="P A L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme.
